Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2007 12:44PM cho wrote: I went in this morning and had the biopsy, and to my surprise they used a larger needle and sucked the whole thing out. Getting that little baby out released a whole lot of stress. Now to find out what it was. My left arm is a little miserable right now but surely by tomorrow it will be okay. As far as the "reliablity of the study", cbl, with as many patients as they get the term "study" is used loosely and actually means it is studied about as much as a flash card would be studied. But discounting their terminology the radiologists that I have dealt with have not ever missed what was most important...and that includes hairline fractures with my kids to mammos with myself. They, so far, have zeroed in on the problems I've needed to deal with so my faith in radiologists is pretty good even though they seem to talk out of both sides of their mouth. Hope you are doing well after your surgery.
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2007 05:03AM cho wrote: I called the pathology department for a copy of my report on the biopsy I had yesterday morning. I asked if they just wanted me to sign a release like I did last week for my radiology report. She said they don't do that any more but I could come in and get a copy. I asked if my doctor had the report and she said it hasn't been signed off on yet and he wouldn't get it until later today. So I can get the report but he can't? I must sound stupid.
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2007 04:49PM cho wrote: Today I had my spot compression and sono gram. If bc is not suppose to hurt then I definitely do NOT have bc because I'm still hurting. The mammo everyone knows is not your choice of afternoon fun and so I thought the worst was over...but geeeeeeeeze...when she pressed that wand over that spot I had no idea....I knew my entire breast was tender but apparently it radiates from that one spot. The tech said the radiologist was on the phone with another doctor...I don't know if the conversation was my business, someone else's business, monkey business...I'm clueless. So I got dressed and went to the waiting room to hear his words of wisdom and all I got was "the radiologist MAY recommend a biopsy." Hello. Something IS in there and it does need to leave me alone. Has anyone ever had something like this??
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2007 05:22PM cho wrote: After I posted it did occur to me that it's probably because they don't think it's a cyst. I really don't either...so I could get surprised. Thanks for your input. It keeps me sane.
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2007 06:40AM cho wrote: Okay. My doctor's nurse just called and said the pathology report was not in and would not be in until later today or tomorrow. The report that stated what they did is all that is available...and I know WHAT they did...I was there. So maybe I did sound stupid. I didn't know there was such a report. The girl in pathology and I just didn't connect...maybe. Where is the valium when you need one?? lol
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2007 06:08AM cho wrote: My doctor's office called today and my biopsy report was okay. She said it showed evidence of fibrocystic disease...already knew that. But, hey, I'm happy and happy the wait is over. Just goes to show that NOT every report that says "irregular borders" is cancer. For those of you still waiting....hang in there. Don't lose hope. And even if it is bc is so cureable...Thank you for listening, once again.
Posts.Title: in limbo cho Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2007 08:17AM cho wrote: Thanks, Beesie, I needed that! I have read that pain doesn't usually accompany breast cancer, although I did read on another site that cancers are usually not round but more oval shaped. I wish they would cut straight to a biopsy. Looking at something isn't the same thing as having it right there under the microscope. My mother is a cancer survivor (uterine), her mother had bc and bone cancer. My half-sister died of cancer (cervical) at 30 and it really wasn't until I read the radiology report that (that had MY name on it) I thought hey, I'm not so special that I couldn't get this disease also. 48 and still a dummy! Thank you for your encouragement. Carla

Posts.Content: cho wrote: I am 48 years old, had a complete hysterectomy at 36 so I have been menopausing for about 12 years now. Had a mammogram that showed a 7-8 mm ovoid nodule in my left breast. Left breast is definitely more tender than my right although I do have fibrocystic garbage in both of them. My left armpit is puffy, my left arm is achy...a spot compression and a sonogram are ordered for next Friday. Does anything here sound like it's NOT cancer? I can handle it but not knowing is so consuming. Thanks for your input. Log in to post a reply
